item.dc:creator: @Full_Metalst Full Metalst
item.description:
@Full_Metalst wrote:

fellixombc:

I thought java docs on suns website were made for a reason instead of this terrible user tutorials?

You can’t actually practice Java on there with getting checked, at least, I don’t think so. Why are you acting like you know everything?

@blah bah7: You don’t have to seem like a jerk about it.

@cooper: It’s something like ‘lolwut’, it means ‘okay…’ Lots of people do it, even in school, I’ve had handouts that had ‘…’ in it and that’s SCHOOL.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Exercises
item.dc:creator: @Full_Metalst Full Metalst
item.description:
@Full_Metalst wrote:

If you want the link, then pm me. It’s a very helpful site that will help you out with your Java skills. If there is other ways, then please post, tell me what your outcomes are!

You can go from:

public String helloName(String name) { return "Hello " + name + "!"; }

to

public boolean sleepIn(boolean weekday, boolean vacation) { if (!weekday || vacation) { return true; } else { return false; } }

By the way, this was all by me, from scratch ;).

Here’s a pretty difficult one for me, had to see the solutions to most of them:

public boolean posNeg(int a, int b, boolean negative) { if (negative) { return (a < 0 && b < 0); } else { return ((a < 0 && b > 0 || a > 0 && b < 0)); } }

It was really difficult, I looked at the arrows and the last return, because it was just way too difficult.

public boolean icyHot(int temp1, int temp2) { //Written as icyHot int temp1, so you return true if one > 0 < 100; if ((temp1 < 0 && temp2 > 100) || (temp1 > 100 && temp2 < 0)) { return true; } else{ return false; } //Of course, it COULD be written as return ((temp1 < 0 &&...)); }

I looked at the show solution, but after I got it right the first time, I kept trying to remember it. Then, I got it right with just memorizing the material.

public boolean in1020(int a, int b) { //I was given 2 int values, then it said return true if either of them is in the range 10..20 etc. return ((a >= 10 && a <= 20) || (b >= 10 && b <= 20)); }

Same with this one. I always have to look at the solution before I try it out, but I looked at “Return if 10…20 and so on”, so I thought “Okay”, so I knew it had to be a return with those ints and the 2 numbers. Then I looked at the solution and went “Oh…” because I didn’t understand why the arrow needed an “=” sign. Oh well.

public boolean hasTeen(int a, int b, int c) { return (a>=13 && a<=19) || (b>=13 && b<=19) || (c>=13 && c<=19); }

This one was a new one for me, I never knew you could do this in Java. I pretty much just quickly looked at the solution, and I was like “Wtf?”, then I just fucked it all up. So I memorized the solution, then I did it on my own, and I passed.

[code]public boolean loneTeen(int a, int b) {
//Directions: Given 2 int values, return true if one or the other is teen, but not both
boolean aTeen = (a>=13) && (a<=19);
boolean bTeen = (b>=13) && (b<=19);

return (aTeen && !bTeen) || (!aTeen && bTeen);
}[/code]

This one confused the hell out of me, but I practiced, and then finally made it from scratch.

I will put some of the codes that I made here. I will write a Java tutorial also.

Read full topic
